That's a great goal! Swimming a mile without stopping requires a good amount of endurance, technique, and mental toughness. With consistent practice and progressive overload, you can definitely achieve your goal. Here's a rough outline to help you structure your swimming plan:

**Weeks 1-4:**

* Start with 20-30 minutes of swimming, 3 times a week
* Swim at a moderate pace, with regular breaks to catch your breath and recover
* Focus on building your endurance and technique, incorporating drills and exercises to improve your efficiency
* Aim to swim 400-500 yards without stopping by the end of week 4

**Weeks 5-8:**

* Gradually increase your swimming time to 30-40 minutes, 3 times a week
* Introduce interval training to improve your cardiovascular fitness and endurance
* Incorporate strength training exercises to target your shoulders, back, and core (2-3 times a week)
* Aim to swim 600-700 yards without stopping by the end of week 8

**Weeks 9-12:**

* Increase your swimming time to 40-50 minutes, 3 times a week
* Introduce longer intervals and more challenging sets to simulate swimming a mile
* Focus on building your mental toughness and endurance, practicing visualization techniques and positive self-talk
* Aim to swim 800-900 yards without stopping by the end of week 12

**Weeks 13-16:**

* Swim at a high intensity, aiming to complete a mile without stopping
* Incorporate active recovery techniques, such as stretching and foam rolling, to aid in your recovery
* Focus on fine-tuning your technique and pacing, making adjustments as needed
* Celebrate your achievement and enjoy the sense of accomplishment!

Remember to listen to your body and adjust your plan as needed. It's better to err on the side of caution and take rest days or modify your workout than to risk injury or burnout.

How does this rough outline sound? Do you have any specific questions or concerns about your swimming plan?
